title: 103_hr107
content: The Act may be cited as the "Congressional Accountability Act of 1993". The Congressional Accountability Act of 1993 mandates that laws related to employment terms, health and safety, and employer-employee rights apply to Congress as they do to private individuals and Executive agencies. The Congressional Accountability Act of 1993 extends certain laws, such as the Social Security Act and the Civil Rights Act of 1964, to apply to Congress. The Congressional Accountability Act of 1993 extends various laws to apply to Congress, including Title IX of the Education Amendments of 1972, the Rehabilitation Act of 1973, the Privacy Act of 1974, the Age Discrimination Act of 1975, the Ethics in Government Act of 1978, and the Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990. Congress and its instrumentalities are subject to the Freedom of Information Act to the same extent as Executive agencies. The Congressional Accountability Act of 1993 extends various laws to apply to Congress, including the Freedom of Information Act and the Independent Counsel Provisions of title 28, United States Code. This Act applies to Senators, Representatives, Resident Commissioners, and Delegates in Congress. The Congressional Accountability Act of 1993 applies to Members of Congress, employees of Congress, Capitol Police, and employees of Congressional instrumentalities. Employees of Congressional instrumentalities, including the Congressional Research Service, General Accounting Office, Library of Congress, and others, are subject to the laws set forth in the Congressional Accountability Act of 1993. The district or State office is treated as an affiliated branch of a private employer under the laws in section 2. Members may consider political affiliation and place of residence when hiring staff. Section 509 of the Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990 is repealed. Small business exemptions in laws apply to Members. The small business exemption applies to Members based on the number of employees, including those attributable to the Member. The number of employees attributable to a Member is calculated based on specific criteria and divided by the number of Members in that House. SEC. 3. PROMULGATION OF IMPLEMENTING REGULATIONS. The House of Representatives and the Senate must create rules within 180 days to implement the Act. Failure to do so will result in being subject to Executive agency regulations. SEC. 4. RIGHT OF APPEAL. SEC. 4. RIGHT OF APPEAL. Individuals affected by actions under this Act can seek review in Federal court with the same rights as private persons under relevant laws.
